conclusion: To determine whether light beam b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light beam a, we need to consider several factors related to the properties of light and the setup described in the question.

Diffraction is a phenomenon that occurs when light waves encounter an obstacle or a slit that is comparable in size to their wavelength. It results in the bending and spreading of waves around the edges of the obstacle.
The frequency (f) and wavelength (λ) of light are related by the equation c = f · λ, where c is the speed of light in a vacuum.
Higher frequency light has a shorter wavelength, and lower frequency light has a longer wavelength.
Light beams a and b have different frequencies.
Both beams intersect at point P inside the glass brick after refraction.

premise: Diffraction is more pronounced for longer wavelengths (lower frequency) because they are more comparable to typical obstacle sizes.
conclusion: If light beam b has a lower frequency than light beam a, it would be more likely to exhibit diffraction.
The beams are incident perpendicularly onto the flat surface AB, meaning they enter the glass without any initial angle of incidence.
The beams intersect at point P inside the glass, indicating refraction has occurred.
Refraction depends on the wavelength of light; different wavelengths bend differently when passing through a medium.
The refractive index of the glass affects how much each beam bends.

premise: Without specific information about the frequencies of beams a and b, we cannot definitively say which beam has a longer wavelength.
conclusion: If beam b has a lower frequency (and thus a longer wavelength) than beam a, it would indeed be more likely to exhibit diffraction.
